ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
INCREASE IN PETROL PUMP PRICES
(Rationale)


    1. Mr Tan Soo Khoon asked the Minister for Trade and Industry what is the rationale for the recent increase in petrol pump prices.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, first let me say how honoured I am to have been asked the first question by the former Speaker.

    With growing tension in the Middle East, oil prices have been going up and we are seeing this reflected in the prices of petrol.

    Generally speaking, petrol pump prices are determined by market demand and supply. Consumer demand for the various grades of petrol determines the overall demand. On the supply side, costs depend on several factors, including the costs of storage and distribution, the prices of crude oil and wholesale petrol, and the foreign exchange rates. Crude oil prices account for about 20% of the pump price. In the short run, as consumer demand does not adjust rapidly, changes in pump prices generally reflect changes in these cost factors. However, because of the oligopolistic structure of the industry, prices tend to be sticky both ways.

    The Consumers Association of Singapore (CASE) has asked the oil companies

Column: 347

to justify the recent increases in petrol pump prices. One of the oil companies, ExxonMobil, has explained in detail in the Straits Times on 28th March that the rise in wholesale petrol prices since January this year was the main factor that contributed to its decision to raise petrol pump prices.

    The key question is whether there is price fixing by the oil companies. Looking at the fluctuations, the Ministry of Trade and Industry finds no evidence of collusion by the oil companies either to restrict supply or to raise prices. Either would be frowned upon by the Government and would be illegal once we put in place a Competition Law.

    The recent price increases follow decreases in petrol prices last year. For the period between July 2001 and December 2001, crude oil prices fell by approximately 26%. Around the same period, and after taking into account a time lag, petrol pump prices fell by 14%. Part of this reflected the reduction in petrol taxes announced in October 2001 as part of the off-Budget measures. I have circulated a chart showing changes in the prices of crude oil and petrol from 1993 to February this year. Last year, I circulated a similar chart.
Import Price Index for Crude Oil (1998 = 100) and Consumer Price Index for Petrol (1998 = 100) - January 1993 - February 2002


    To keep the retail market for petrol as competitive as possible, our policy is to facilitate the entry of independent petrol retailers. Last year, I announced to the House that we were planning to introduce "white pumpers". These are petrol-pumping facilities annexed to supermarkets and commercial buildings. MND has identified several sites but detailed studies need to be made to ensure that safety, traffic flow and environmental requirements can be met. After September 11, the security considerations have become more severe and this has caused a delay in the sites that we intend to let out for white pumps. Some parties have expressed interest to operate these white pumps.

Column: 348



    Mr Tan Soo Khoon (East Coast): Sir, if there is no price fixing among the major petroleum companies, why is it that price increases are always more or less by the same quantum amongst the oil companies, and why is it that the price increase takes place almost on the same day?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is a well known phenomenon in economics. When an industry structure reflects high fixed cost and, where there are few players involved, normally, the lowest cost producer will be the price leader and the rest will follow suit. In such an industry, there is a tendency for price instability and for price wars to happen. So the smaller players have to be very careful not to trigger off a chain of events which may lead to price wars and they will normally take the lead from the price leader. This is called monopolistic competition by some economists. It reflects the nature of competition in oligopolistic structures. The airline industry faces the same problem. Many chemical industries face the same problem.

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon: Sir, if that is the case, why is it that the smallest petroleum company in Singapore, which is the Singapore Petroleum Company, with only five or six outlets in Singapore has managed to keep its price low and has not increased price and, in fact, is offering a discount?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not know, but I can guess that its position in the market is too small for it to cause sufficient reaction from the other players. Oil companies compete in different ways, some offer free tissue paper, some offer loyalty programmes. So there are different ways to compete and to hold on to your customers. The question is: should MTI intervene in the market? We should intervene if it is clear that there is abuse of dominant position, or if there is price fixing. As I said, if you look at the chart which I have distributed and if I may draw Members' attention to it, we have two indices, one is crude oil prices which

Column: 349

fluctuate quite a lot and are going up again because of tension in the Middle East. Then we have fluctuating with a time lag, in a much more sticky way, variations in the price of premium petrol. I can understand why as consumers we get very upset when we see pump prices going up. When pump prices go down, it attracts less attention. This is natural as consumers. These indices reflect nominal prices. If you look at the price in January this year and compare it to, say, January 1993, nominal prices have not changed very much. But I do not think that on the basis of prices we can draw an automatic conclusion that oil companies are deliberately fixing oil prices at high levels.

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon: One last question, Sir. Would it not be more logical to suggest that the larger oil companies, and quite naturally, will enjoy larger economies of scale than the smallest oil company and they are in a better position to follow the price set by the smallest company which is, I presume, still making good profits?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not familiar with the prices offered by these five SPC outlets. I do not know whether they have the same loyalty programme, whether they offer the same free gifts and points ---

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon: $1.234 less 10%.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Do they offer the same points?

    Mr Tan Soo Khoon: No.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Consumers will make their own decision whether they want to collect points, or whether they want to take lower upfront prices. But let us say that Mr Tan is right that these five outlets offer prices which are much lower than the other retail outlets, then consumers will vote with their wheels, which means that when new sites are available for tendering, SPC will be able to offer higher prices for these sites because they are much more competitive. In other words, the market should be able to resolve this problem, if there is a problem.

Column: 350



    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay (Chua Chu Kang): The Minister tries to justify that there is no price fixing among the oil companies. So he tries to use the crude oil price in relation to the premium petrol price. If you really look at the drastic increase and fluctuations of the crude oil price as compared with the relatively moderate fluctuation of the premium petrol price from the chart, I would like to ask the Minister does he arrive at the conclusion that, at the moment, in fact, the oil companies are making lesser profit as a result of the adjustment of the pump price. That is the first question.

    The second question is that the chart does not reflect the profit level of the oil companies. I think what people are actually unhappy about is the high petrol price and that has resulted in high profits by the petroleum companies. So if you look at the international petroleum spot price, I would like the Minister to comment whether I am right or not on this particular matter. The international petroleum spot price for 98 RON petrol ---

    Mr Speaker: Mr Low, could you ask your question?

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay: I am asking my question.

    Mr Speaker: Please do so.

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay: I am asking the Minister whether I am right or not. The 98 RON petrol price based on the international petroleum spot price on 12th March this year was 32.9 cents per litre and the pump price, after deduction of the Government tax, the margin gained was 42.4 cents. Assuming that I am not familiar with the cost of operation - the cost is not much because we are very competitive in terms of our so-called business costs - they are making 130% margin from the international petroleum spot price. I would like to ask the Minister whether this kind of margin is acceptable.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not really in a position to answer that question. The data is not available to me. We do not require them to be

Column: 351

presented or audited by any regulatory agency. It may be that there is a higher margin, but then the cost of distributing petrol is not cheap either. They have got to tender for the sites. They have got to ensure that safety is maintained. They have got to hire people, many operate 24 hours. The cost structure varies from industry to industry, from product to product, and the fact that there is a high margin over the wholesale price, by itself, does not indicate anything.

    A matter of principle is this. Should Government be concerned with whether oil companies are making money or losing money? If we decide that we are going to regulate prices and regulate profits, then there is no end to it. Some years ago, one major oil company protested strenuously to MTI that MND was releasing more sites for petrol pumps. It had earlier tendered for sites thinking that we are going to restrict the number of these sites and so it paid a lot of money at the tender. So he came to me and said, "Look. Yes, it was not legal but surely there was an understanding." I said, "I am sorry. MND has its own policy on the release of sites for petrol pumps and these are the risks that you take." So we are not responsible for the losses they make, neither are we responsible for the profits they make. But for Dr Low's exact question as to whether the margins are justifiable or not, I am in no position to answer his question.

    Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Aljunied): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister what measure will MTI consider to ensure that consumers' interest will be safeguarded in sectors like this where there is little or no competition. Besides white pumps, how can we introduce more competition into the petrol retail sector?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, we are open to suggestions. White pump was an idea suggested to us slightly over a year ago and we thought it was a good idea. White pumps are available in some countries, like Britain, where they have attained a certain market share and so we decided to introduce them. If CASE

Column: 352

or anyone here has got ideas on how to introduce more competition to the business, MTI keeps an open mind. There is no reason for us to want to restrict competition.

    Our general policy towards the economy is that competition is good and competition should be encouraged. Should we regulate to ensure competition, like through a Competition Law, which is the question which has been raised a few times in this House? There is a draft being circulated among the Ministries and various economic agencies. There are a lot of problems because, sometimes, when you regulate to force competition, you may in fact end up creating anti-competitive practices and imposing a higher cost on the economy. The key is to regulate, but regulate lightly. Right now, the various regulatory agencies are responsible for competitive behaviour within the sectors they regulate, eg, in telecoms, power, health care or whatever. But whether there should be an overarching competition law, it is something that we are now considering seriously. We have not decided definitely to proceed. It is likely that we will, but the details are very important and we are making sure that before we present a Bill to this House, we have consulted widely with the industries.

    Dr Teo Ho Pin (Holland-Bukit Panjang): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Minister whether the increase in oil prices will lead to an increase in electricity tariffs, and whether the Government will soften the impact on consumers and businesses, if there is any such increase.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: The increases in energy prices must be reflected in electricity tariffs. I think that is necessary. We must ensure that the signals get passed through to the economy so that every consumer and every industry makes its own adjustments to these price signals. Should the Government ameliorate it? I would be against the Government ameliorating it directly, because then we would be making electricity artificially cheaper and, if we do so, there will be an over

Column: 353

consumption of electricity. But the Government can always ameliorate its effects through income support, which this Government does from time to time.

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay: The Minister does not seem to answer my question whether the profits are acceptable. I would like to ask the Minister, because he touched on the issue of tender prices for petrol kiosks.

    Based on the tender prices that have been accepted in the past, I would like the Minister to comment whether I am right that they are still very profitable based on the following scenario. When a petrol station is available for tender and the land is about 30,000 square feet, the common tender price will be around $10 million. If we work that out in simple mathematical terms, it will be around $300 per square foot for a 30-year lease. If, let us say the price works out to be equivalent to a 99-year lease, the tender price for a petrol station in a noisy, dirty and very unattractive roadside would be even more than that for an Oxley Road residential land. If they tender for a piece of land at that kind of price and the profit is not good, why should they do so? Could the Minister prove that I am wrong.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not quite sure I understand the point of Prof. Low's question. If it is so self-evident that running a petrol kiosk is so profitable, then I am quite sure that the next time sites are available, Prof. Low will be one of those who will tender for those sites.

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay: Sir, I accept the challenge if I can run a petrol company.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Fourth Allotted Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [1st April, 2002],

    'That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".' - [Mrs Lim Hwee Hua].

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Ong Kian Min (Tampines): Mr Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate. Today is the fourth day of this debate. As more than 40 speakers have already risen to speak, I would just like to focus on a couple of specific issues. I support the Motion of Thanks to the President moved by Mrs Lim Hwee Hua.

Competition is global

    In his Address, the President has highlighted the immense challenges we face and the impact of global competition. Indeed, competition is global and is coming not just from China and the region. The World Economic Forum recently reported that Singapore's global growth competitiveness has slipped two notches from second to fourth placing.

    For many years, Singapore has been holding the No. 1 or No. 2 position, and our good rating has been well publicised. But little has been said about the drop in our ranking this time round. For the first time, we have been overtaken by Finland and Canada. Fast closing up behind us include Australia, Norway and Taiwan, whose rankings have improved by three to nine positions within one year.

The need to stay ahead

    What we do to tackle the present challenges determines our future. Do we despair and lose hope, do nothing and allow others to overtake us? Do we dismiss it and be content with the slack,

Column: 355

thinking that things must somehow get better when the world economy gets moving again? Or are we content to say there is no need to stay at the top all the time? If our answer to the above questions is yes, we run the risk of being tossed out of the race and get left behind. We have to regain speed, make bold strides to catch up and stay ahead.

    We must not be daunted by the challenges before us. We must not be disheartened or feel hopeless. On the contrary, we can turn them to our advantage. We can do with a healthy dose of the "siege mentality". We, like the employees of successful global companies, should be driven with a sense of urgency and purpose. We must not be complacent. Microsoft, the No. 1 PC software company, has been described to behave as if it were No. 2 and trying to play catch-up all the time. Nokia succeeded in overtaking its much larger competitors who had the first-mover advantage. Now that Nokia is No. 1, it fights even harder to stay ahead. These companies all know that once you slip, you can go all the way down and never return to the days of glory.

Challenges not unique

    The challenges Singapore faces are not unique. I would like to add to what Assoc. Prof. Koo Tsai Kee said yesterday about Hong Kong with my own personal observations. I was in Zhuhai, China, last week. I took the ferry to Hong Kong on Good Friday to catch the SQ flight back home. Going the other way were thousands of Hongkongers leaving Hong Kong for mainland China. The ferries were packed and we had to fight through long queues of people waiting to buy tickets. Hongkongers go to Macau, Zhuhai and Shenzhen by the hundreds of thousands everyday for dinner, movies and other forms of entertainment. On a bad day, one has to stand more than one hour to clear immigration at the Hong Kong-Shenzhen border crossing. Things are cheaper across the waters. People go where they find better value for their money, especially in these lean times. When money

Column: 356

was aplenty, people found it inconvenient to travel a little distance, just to save some money. But, now, where they do not make thousands of dollars in one day just buying and selling shares, or hundreds of thousands of dollars buying and selling properties, every dollar counts.

    Whilst it is important for us to build first-class infrastructure and facilities and adopt the world's best practices, we have to be mindful of the cost burden that local businesses have to bear which, in turn, would translate into higher prices for the consumers. Sir, to overcome this, we have to attract and retain good businesses to our shores which will in turn generate the purchasing power to support other local businesses and make this a thriving place.

People - the differentiating factor

    How then do we achieve competitive differentiation in this global environment? Others can import the same technology and talent to build the same or even better factory, airport and seaport. It must be the people factor that is our strategic resource. Responding to the challenges we face means that we, the people, have to change our mindset.

    Allow me to cite an example. A couple of years ago, I did some renovations to my house and wanted some lighting points fixed up. The main contractor, who drove a Mercedes Benz, asked me to show him where I wanted those lighting points. So I went round the house with him and pointed out the spots. The next day, another man, the electrical sub-contractor, came round in a Honda Accord and told me that he understood I wanted some lights to be put up and he asked me to show him where. I did that. The next day, two men came on a 50cc Honda Cub with Johor number plates and told me that they were there to do the job and asked me to show them where I wanted the lights to be installed.

Knowledge acquisition and skill development

    Sir, the first word in "KBE" is "knowledge". We cannot merely be brokers

Column: 357

and middlemen in a knowledge-based economy. Our workers, our people, must change their mindset and their attitudes. We must want to acquire knowledge.

    A manager of an MNC shared this observation with me. He said that while Singapore workers are hardworking, they do not have an inquiring mind. When a sophisticated high-tech piece of equipment is installed, our workers are generally quite contented to be told how to operate the equipment. They do not have the desire to go beyond that and try to fathom the "whys" and the "hows". They will take instructions on how to operate it and, if something goes wrong, the company has to call in the foreign experts. It is like buying a car and learning how to drive it and not wanting to open the bonnet. If something goes wrong, call the workshop. I know today's automobiles are so sophisticated that there is nothing an amateur mechanic can do if it breaks down, but I hope we know at least how to change the tyre.

    We do not need to acquire the whole technology. Let me cite this example. I know a Norwegian. He is spending a lot of his time now in Singapore. For many years, he was an engineer in Norway installing and maintaining pumps for oil companies in the North Sea. These pumps are part of a larger system. He just concentrated on the pumps. But he was willing to stick to his area of expertise and, in the course of his many years of experience, he found out which areas in the pump can be improved for better performance. Today, he owns a number of patents and he is here selling his own pumps to our GLCs.

    As we move up the economic ladder and progress to the more unstructured "innovation" state, we need to be thinkers and not just mere doers. We need people who question the given and seek new ways to improve. We need to breed more risk-takers and foster an entrepreneurial spirit.

    Sir, there seems to be a misconception that entrepreneurs are necessarily school drop-outs. I know there are a few laudable examples of drop-outs who made it big.

Column: 358

Their success stories grab media attention and create an impression that university education is a hindrance to the development of entrepreneurship. Perhaps, when opportunities are aplenty, it is those with less formal education, those who have to take bigger risks, who have found alternative routes to success. But in today's competitive world, one must not disregard the acquisition of knowledge and skills to have a fighting chance.

    The Managing Director of an MNC told me that the most creative person in his company is the Chief Technology Officer who has doctorates in a number of disciplines and who is willing to think out of the box. With his wealth of technical knowledge and his years of practical experience, he is able to come up with very creative solutions to complex problems, something that a younger person, with less technical know-how and less training, would not be able to do. While we celebrate the success stories of instant entrepreneurs, we must not forget the tens of thousands of scientists, researchers and developers who toil away and churn out patents by the millions and help to sustain the technological development of the largest MNCs of this world and make these successful MNCs what they are today.

    Sir, there are no short cuts. The days of easy money are gone for now. We must be realistic and go back to the basics, to the virtue of work and enterprise.

Developing strong local enterprises

    Although MNCs have and will continue to play a critical role in our economic development, we have to pay more attention to developing local enterprises. It is time that we developed our own indigenous proprietary technology.

Cultivating innovative ideas

    In this regard, the Government has done much in trying to create an environment conducive for innovation. Individual risk-taking is encouraged and failures are not looked down upon. The various economic agencies, the universities and the research institutions are being restructured to meet

Column: 359

the new challenges. Local enterprises have tapped various Government sponsored schemes to their benefit. Funding, grants, tax incentives are in general not an issue for those who have a good idea. But for start-ups, what is really lacking here is a first "reference site" where the entrepreneur can use to fine-tune his ideas for commercial deployment. In a larger, more competitive economy like the US, there are hundreds of competitors out there in any industry, each of them willing to try something new, with the hope that it is a killer application and wipe out the competition. It is not a problem knocking on doors and finding someone willing to give a new idea, a new method, a go. But in a small economy like ours, this must be nurtured.

    The budding talents need a good break in their home ground to build a track record or reference sites before they can hope to debut and achieve success in the competitive global stage. We need to engineer some form of demand-side innovation.

    Sir, Singapore has been described as clean, efficient, safe, and lately, even a funky place. In the global competition among city states, branding and positioning are crucial to attract the right talents and businesses. In addition to the above mentioned descriptions of Singapore, I think we should put ourselves on the map as "the laboratory", the place to experiment.

    Mr Inderjit Singh mentioned yesterday that we should set up a string of technology and research centres around the world where talent is found instead of having just one big centre in Singapore. I would like to disagree with him. relations in his country are good and will not pose a problem in future. He sends his children to Chinese schools and later to overseas universities.     Back to the first point - an artificial country. Geographically, if you go back far enough in time, geological ages, Singapore is at the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula. Now all this ruckus about reclamation is almost ironic humour that geography and geology are playing on us.

that he liked the harbour. Selective immigration occurred even 150 years or more ago. It is a freak of circumstances, not a natural occurrence. The debate, if any, is about the implications of these three forces on our society and how we are going to deal with it.

    If you take an even broader perspective, what is happening really is what the

Column: 366

Tofflers called the "Third wave of change in civilisation". Ten thousand years ago, when mankind discovered agriculture, society changed because they stayed put in one place. Land was important. They grew their crops. Extended families were important because that was their labour source. And if they grew enough crops and the weather was kind to them, they had surpluses and they stored up. That was the original CPF. They prepared for a rainy day, and life went on.

Families became nuclear families instead of extended families. Political power changed from a feudal structure that characterises agricultural society to the two competing models - representative democracy versus totalitarian socialism. With the fall of the Berlin Wall, we know which political model won as far as running an industrial age society is concerned. Economically, it was about land; it was about labour; it was about capital. But what is happening now, when we talk of the information age and knowledge-based economy, is that another paradigm or sea change has occurred in the means of production of wealth. It is now about ideas. It is about social capital, and it is still about money, except it is now global and it is moving very, very quickly.     This is Parliament. This is a form of representative democracy. We are supposed to represent our constituents. But you and I know fully well that in this day and age, it is impossible for any one person to claim or to pretend that he represents all views. We come here as colleagues with our own set of beliefs, ideas, prejudices and biases. We hope that it reflects what the larger society feels and thinks about it, but it is not so simple. in the future. You can, in a sense, have the ultimate expression of democracy because, after all, in a world where everybody is always on and always connected, do you still need Parliament?     There is an optimistic side to the knowledge-based economy. Because in the knowledge-based economy, as opposed to an industrial economy, land, capital, machinery and cheap labour become less important. And the fact that we worry about it and we are thinking about it now actually gives us hope that we will be amongst the first people, the first wave of nations to be able to take advantage of this revolution.

    But there is another side to this issue of globalisation. As the world becomes smaller and smaller, and more and more things become common, we sometimes forget that whilst civilisations can change, 10,000 years is a very, very short time in evolutionary terms. Our genes have not changed, certainly not in the last 10,000 years or even longer. Therefore, human nature has not changed. And what we are experiencing now is the clash of a change in environment impinging and impacting on basically an unchanged human nature. So, in this world which is increasingly interconnected and global, we are suddenly realising that, hey, how I feel and how I think actually disconnects with what is happening around me and what I see around me. And so we get this movement which we loosely call fundamentalism. It is a human reaction against changes which we feel or we fear we have no control over, and which we feel or we

Column: 368

It is a clash of environment versus human nature. And Singapore, as this tiny dot, bobbing around in the sea, surrounded by tsunamis, is not immune to these changes. Our key challenge therefore has to be how to manage some of the problems or consequences of these changes, key amongst which are the economic and cultural disparities. And this is where you see the opposition, and us disagree.

    Let us talk about economics first. We agree that we have to connect ourselves to the world. We have improved our technology. We have to have education, and we have to have free trade. There are two solutions in front of you when you see an increase in income spread. Do not get on the bandwagon, in which case everybody stays the way we are now. But it is not possible, because staying put means you sink to the bottom of the sea. Or we say that we will accept that there will be an increasing income disparity, but the issue is what do we do for those who are falling behind. And the metaphor which I could use is that, yes, we have all talked about safety nets to catch people who fall. But at what point does the safety net becomes a hammock, where you can fall and lie there and say, "This is good enough. I don't need to get up." At what stage do you have to convert a safety net into a trampoline, so that you can say, "Yes, I've fallen off, but there's an inherent spring in this, and I can use it to bounce back up." And the way to bounce back up, although it may be something which our population does not want

Column: 369

to hear, is about training, education, retooling and reskilling. There is no other way to bounce back up from an economy which is changing, because your job has gone, because someone else is doing it more cheaply, or a robot is doing it more efficiently, or because nobody needs that job any more.     At the same time, we still need the trapeze, because you need some people to do those high flying, dare-devil stunts. And do not say, "Well, if you get to fly up on that trapeze, you will be a star and everyone else will be a pedestrian watching." We have to allow people to go up on the trapeze. Let some of them succeed, bring glory to the whole act. But at the same time, we still have got our safety nets, because some of them will also fall. And when they fall, hopefully, they will bounce back up because we have converted our safety nets into trampolines.

You cannot rely on the models which existed in the past or the models which exist currently in Malaysia, India, China or the West to use as lessons for how we need to do it. Our ethnic groups must realise that isolation is not an option. Reverting to medieval times is not an option. Copying other countries is not an option. We have got to understand this principle of co-determinism, that what happens to the Malays, the Chinese or the Indians in Singapore is not something which you will decide individually as a Malay, a Chinese or an Indian. When people talked about collective leadership for the Malay community, what they did not understand is this concept of co-determinism. The ultimate fate of the Malays in Singapore is going to be determined not by the Malays alone, but by all of us and, similarly, for the Indians and for the Chinese. And if we

start creating a system where we say this is my problem, my business and I will lead it, I will be pre-eminent and predominant in making decisions on that exclusively, that is the beginning of the end because we will unravel the whole thing. So we need to move beyond this. The Government is obsessively secular, and I think we must continue to be, because that is the best guarantee for religious freedom and religious security in Singapore.

    Let us talk about the hearts and the minds. Samuel Huntington has said that in the future our loyalties will be determined by what we believe rather than where we live, and this applies, I think, very much to Singapore.     Yes, we have been very stiff about saying, wipe out dialects, wipe out Singlish, but the truth of the matter is, there is emotion resonance in these. reports also say that more often than not, after the downsizing process, most companies do not earn more, they just spend less. Each type of plant has its own system of ensuring its own uniqueness and its survival. Yet, hybrids appear in forms not imaginable before. The bougainvillea may creep into loops and hang at the most curious places, sometimes even among other plants.

    In the context of inter-community relations, we acknowledge that each community has traits which are unique to itself and each community has an interest to guard its identity. Yet, every community interacts with the others, without one having to fear of being subsumed by the other. On top of it all, it is the common will to ensure peace and security so as to facilitate the continuous development of each community and to facilitate the meaningful interaction among communities. The design and plan of the gardener represent this common will of the people. Without the common will, there is no nation. Without the gardener, we have no garden. Belukar, maybe. Sir, Singapore is indeed a garden city in more senses than one may think.

    Sir, while it may be pleasing to indulge in this garden metaphor, in reality, inter-community relations is a very intricate matter. To allow each community to retain its own unique characteristics while at the same time moving towards national interaction is to unleash two forces that may pull in opposite directions. I wish to humbly caution that the road to appreciation is arduous. There are three aspects of this road I wish to highlight. The first is that it requires each ethnic religious or cultural group to be more open with one another. For some, it requires a change of mindset. There are many beliefs which the community holds jealously, kept to itself for years and for centuries, but these now have to be exposed, lest such secrecy may arouse suspicion. For some, it requires a change of environment. If you have been avoiding discussing sensitive issues in public in order to maintain peace and harmony, now we have to discuss such issues in public in order to pursue the greater appreciation of peace and harmony.

    Sir, recently, there was a short programme on the BBC regarding the causes of extremism and fundamentalism. Almost all the fundamentalists agree that the growth of extremism is inversely proportionate to freedom of expression. In other words, the greater the clamp down on expression, the higher the

Column: 378

chances that these pent-up emotions would be channelled through extremist outlets.

    The second aspect of this road to appreciation is that, by opening up, if not handled carefully, it may have a negative effect. Expressions of differing and opposing views on cultural or religious basis can heighten these differences. They can cause more tension instead of cohesion. The challenge, of course, is how to pursue the engagement process in spite of many controversies that may arise as we open the lid on sensitive issues.

    The third aspect is the need to maintain and develop a comfort base. Even right now, we cannot discuss the things the way we do without first obtaining a certain degree of comfort and confidence among each other. This we have achieved over the years through various measures, such as effective national education, national service, intercultural activities and bilingualism. These are good efforts that will maintain the present comfort level. But to progress towards appreciation, Sir, we need to do more.

    To allow effective engagement on sensitive issues, I believe that three points must be looked into. Firstly, each community must be very clear in themselves of their position on several points. The first point is that groups must be clear of their position as regards the development or changes in attitudes of the members of each flock towards their race, culture or religion. The variety of such attitudes over time and space has to be understood. No group is always static or totally homogenous in its attitude towards its own race, culture or religion. This variety has to be appreciated, otherwise we would tend to draw general conclusions from specific instances and this does not reflect the actual situation.

    Each group also needs to be clear on its position regarding intolerance and extremism, including an understanding of what causes extremism, what factors affect extremism and how to counter extremism or intolerance. Yet, each group

Column: 379

has to reconcile between its understandable desire to eventualise, to promote itself, yet at the same time, being mindful of contradicting positions taken by other groups with the need to maintain the comfort base.

    Each group, Sir, also needs to clarify for itself how it views interaction among different groups in the physical, restricted confines of Singapore island, reclamation notwithstanding. We wish to avoid a situation whereby inter-group relations are progressing, but at the same time inter-group relations are having strains. In this regard, each group should identify the items within its own value system that has the potential to cause conflict with the second nature of the state and conflicts with other groups. These items that can cause conflict have to be honestly dealt with in a manner that moves towards the long-term outcome of peace and harmony.

    Lastly, Sir, each group also has to have a clear position as regards the role of race, religion and culture in the long-term future. Inter-group appreciation is a long-term desire. And each group needs to search within itself the values and principles it makes to remain relevant, meaningful and contributive to the well-being of this country.

    Sir, if each group is not totally sufficiently clear on the above points, then I humbly suggest that they embark on serious studies on them. While we all wish to accelerate this engagement process, it is worthless, if not dangerous, if the engagement process is supported by ill-prepared ideas and thoughts.

    Secondly, Sir, for effective engagement, each group must be willing to share its views and engage others on them. While each group should search for common views among other groups, yes, each must be prepared to face and deal with diametrically opposing views as well. Each group must give its commitment to maintain the engagement process. This commitment can be enhanced by the

Column: 380

Government making policies that seek to unify while recognising differences, which it is already doing now, but this can be strengthened by (1) ensuring adequate representation of such differing views in national debates; and (2) incorporating greater flexibility as a feature for policies so as to cater for differences. Also the communities, when expressing their views, must do so sensibly and sensitively so as not to undermine the comfort level. Because if the comfort level is undermined, so would the whole engagement process.

    The third point as regards effective engagement, Sir, is that confidence builds upon itself. Confidence building is an accumulative process. As we move 10 paces forward, we would face issues that may cause us to take two steps back. But this does not mean that we retrogress for we would have by then moved eight paces forward. The journey will be full of stops, or such stops, and step-backs. But we all must agree to maintain the general direction at a steady pace.

    Sir, I agree with the hon. Member Assoc. Prof. Koo that we should not allow the rumour of gloom and doom to fulfil its own prophecy. We must have the confidence to come up better, including this area of social cohesion. As I have said, confidence builds upon itself. If there is no confidence amongst us now, we cannot have any confidence in future for there is nothing to build on.

Column: 381

his travels. At one point, my wife asked him, "So, is Singapore nice?" His answer was, "No. Singapore not nice. Singapore very, very nice."

    Sir, I support the motion.

students to our embassy in Beijing to be interviewed. Quite often, the officers in charge have many other duties, and this is not a priority for him. Building Bonds

    The Chinese have a healthy respect for Singapore's reputation. They like the social environment, the cleanliness and the safety in Singapore. As a result, many of the Chinese parents feel secure in sending their children to Singapore for studies. Many of the students studying in Singapore on Government scholarships, grants or on personal expenses, come from families where their parents are well-placed or are important Government officials. We should actively build bonds with Chinese students who study in Singapore. The friendship and bonds will strengthen the bonds between Singapore and China. We must not underestimate the value of these bonds.

    There is another pool which we have not tapped on. These are Chinese nationals who have either become

Column: 385

permanent residents or citizens. Their intimate knowledge of the Chinese way of doing things and the good relations they have with their friends and relatives in China, can potentially smoothen our access into the Chinese market and shorten our learning curve.

Improving the Government and the civil service

    To face these economic challenges, we not only need new engines of growth, but we must ask ourselves how can we improve the internal operating milieu in Singapore. We must improve the Government and the civil service. Government must accept that it is not always right. Ministries which put up legislation in Parliament or which discuss policy issues with MPs should not only explain policies but must also be willing to acknowledge differences in opinion whenever there is room for improvement. It remains now for the Government to show that there is resolve and earnestness to remake the Government. If we cannot remake the Government, how can we talk about remaking Singapore?

The civil service must remember that it is not wrong to empathise with the ordinary Singaporean.

If the businesses fail, jobs will be lost and it will be worse off for everyone. Column: 387

knees and was at his wits' end. He finally sought my assistance to appeal to the Government. After writing to the Ministers concerned, I am glad that his appeal was allowed. However, through no fault of his, he had lost time and money.

We also have an awareness of each other's religions and practices. And these are important foundations and we must treasure them.

I would have liked to have found out what percentage of those students had close or even best friends who were from other races, and how often they socialised with them outside school. While it is good for a Chinese or Malay student to know that Deepavali is the Festival of Lights celebrated by the Hindus, would it not be far better for him to have a good Hindu friend who can not only furnish him with the answer but, better still, invite him to celebrate the festival with his family? Would it not be better even as we share each other's food over a social meal, we were also comfortable enough to share each other's hopes, aspirations and fears?

Column: 398

for this higher paradigm in inter-ethnic relations, one underpinned by deep friendships and bonds of mutual trust.

    I was inspired by recent discussions and dialogues that were held on a variety of issues pertaining to the Muslim community in Singapore, in particular on madrasahs, the tudung issue and the Malays in the SAF, while I thought the outcomes may not have pleased everyone, the process was sincere, serious and dignified.     Sir, I believe the Government should commit itself to a constant review of its policies to ensure that they engender more of such friendships and to ensure that it can remove any impediments that might lie in their path.

But over the years, we have introduced a range of policies and programmes that have been based on ethnicity and language - ethnic quotas in HDB estates, self-help groups, GRCs, SAP schools are some examples. Some of these policies seek to further integrate Singaporeans. Others were designed to meet certain objectives but might have had the unintended consequence of further segregating us. I think it is hard to really assess what the cumulative effect has been on our society. At best, I would say opinion is divided.

The purpose is not to discard policies that have served us well, but to take stock and to ensure that in their totality, they continue to move us in the right direction in pursuit of this ideal. sion that this is the responsibility of Government alone. I think each and every Singaporean has a role to play, and our schools are a good starting point. So perhaps our principals, vice-principals and teachers could be trained, counselled or made aware so that they can deal with such situations tactfully, preferably imperceptibly, as and when they emerge in the classroom, the school field or in the canteen.

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion.

    The theme of the debate on the President's Address has been the remaking of Singapore. Remaking in the sense of new policies, also in the sense of the process by which the new policies are developed, the involvement, the consultation, the debate, the to-and-fro, the binding together of views to develop a national consensus. There is a strong desire, I think, among a significant proportion of the well-educated public for meaningful participation in this process. And there are encouraging signs that in fact this process is developing. Letters in the Forum page now often attract well-argued rebuttals, and no longer require official replies. We have people who spend their time reading the Forum page, scanning for letters which need correction. In the old days, an error would be tracked straightaway. Nowadays, if we wait a couple of days, somebody else will come back with an opposite way, and quite often a very sensible and balanced correction, and we can allow the debate to play itself out. So, I think we are going in the right direction. The Government is convinced that this is the right way forward and is committed to involving Singaporeans in the process of consultation.

    One main exercise doing this is the Economic Review Committee. We are leaving no stone unturned in our review of economic policies, whether it is labour, whether it is manufacturing, whether it is services, whether it is taxes, in order to ensure that Singapore prospers in the years ahead. We are taking some time to do this.

    Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked yesterday: Why is it so long? Is it because the civil servants have no ideas? I assure him that it is not because the civil servants have no ideas. It is because we are dealing with

Column: 401

long-term measures, having already dealt with the immediate measures last year, in October/November, in a $11 billion special off-Budget package. We are considering major changes which need to be carefully weighed. And we are taking our consultations extremely seriously. In fact, if we had acted sooner, he might have accused us of not taking the feedback with the seriousness which it deserves. But we have to take the consultations seriously and we have to take views and make sure that what comes out is in fact fully cooked and properly deliberated.

    The real constraint on the pace of our progress is not the Government; it is not the civil service or the bureaucracy. It is the people. How quickly can the people accept new policies and adapt to change? That is the question. Because new policies are unsettling, people need time to get used to it, accept it, understand it, and argue about it. And we need time to understand how to get the policies packaged, polished, rough edges smoothed off, and implemented.

    We are not sending all sacred cows to the slaughterhouse. Mr Lim Boon Heng said we should consider sending some sacred cows to the slaughterhouse. We are not sending all of them. But I assure you that we should send all our sacred cows, at the very least, to the vet for a thorough examination to make sure that they are healthy or, if they are not healthy, something can be done.

    We pride ourselves that in Singapore no issue is too sensitive to be talked about, nothing is taboo which cannot be discussed. If you raise a subject, we will debate it. If there is a problem, it will be solved. But still some issues are very sensitive - even to raise, never mind to tackle. But we are talking about a fundamental review in a new situation, in a different world, and unless we grasp the nettle and address these issues now, the problems are going to grow and are going to become even harder to tackle.

    The review process has to be managed. We are talking about many people. We are talking about many views. We have

Column: 402

to discuss issues without alarming people. We have to implement issues without jarring the system, but we must be prepared to discuss many fundamental areas which we have taken for granted. As the President said, "No policy is so cast in stone that it can never be changed.".

    The challenge for us is to fix things that ain't broke yet. If something is broken, it is quite easy. Everybody can see it is no longer working, we have to abandon it, something has to replace it. But when something is not broken, but you can see difficulties and problems down the road, then we have to manage that, and it is not so easy. Because, first, we have to persuade people that we do have a problem. And they will say, "Why do you want to raise the subject at all? Matters are working fine." And, secondly, if our policies are still working, we want to make the changes and derive the benefits of making the changes without losing the benefits of the old policies because they are still working, they have served us well, and we do not want to change them. I think in the case of several major fundamental economic policies, we have to address them and approach them with this mindset.

    I will cite three just as examples, which are important ones: the CPF, our wage policies and tax policies.

    First, the CPF. It is one of the cornerstones of our social safety net. It provides for workers, for their medical benefits, for their housing, for their retirement benefits, even for their children to go to university, and to borrow from the CPF. It is funded, it is sound. It is a valuable instrument which we have patiently built up over many years. But we now have to look at it again. We have to reconcile business costs versus workers' needs. We have got to trade off multiple purposes to which the CPF might be put. How much to go into housing, how much to go into medical, how much to go into retirement, how to balance them, what are the priorities. We have to examine the structure of the CPF more closely, to balance between these different uses and to ask some basic questions. As Mr Lim Boon Heng

Column: 403

suggested yesterday, are we investing too much money in housing?

    We should also ask, how do we get the members not just to leave the money with the Government in the CPF and earn 2.5% interest, which over 40, 50 years of our working life is really not enough, but to invest the money in pension funds for better long-term returns at acceptable risk, not to take it out and have a punt on the stock market, not to splurge it on a consumption binge, but to invest it prudently with a portfolio, with professional managers who will not guarantee you a return every year but over five, 10, 20 years, will offer you much better than the Government can offer at 2.5% interest.

    So we have to examine the structure of the CPF. We also have to examine the specific problem of older workers with CPF - older workers meaning those nearly 55, maybe from 50 years onwards - having difficulty finding replacement jobs, because the job market is changing, and they are not willing to work for low take-home pay because they still have families to look after. And if you say 20% knocked off for CPF, because that is his contribution, he says, "Well, take-home $700, not worth my while to work." Often, therefore, they are doing odd jobs for cash, with no CPF at all. And we see them, they come to our meet-the-people sessions, we ask them: What are you doing? And the standard answer is sua kang, which means working for cash rather than for CPF.

    For this group of people, nearly 55 years old, not very well-educated in many cases, would a lower CPF rate make them more employable? It is to be considered. What about their obligations? They may have committed to houses. They may not have finished paying for their mortgages. This is an issue which we have to think about. But, in my view, the overall CPF contribution rate, which is 40% as a target rate, is something which we should maintain. We are not there yet, we are back to 36% after the package in 1998. But we have stated that 40% is our target, and I think

Column: 404

we keep that target. We promise to restore it when we made the CPF cut in 1998/99, and I think we should uphold our promise to the workers. And I do not see any justification to see the CPF below 40% in general, because if you consider the needs of the workers, housing, medical and pension, 40% is not excessive.

    So that is the first sacred cow which needs a medical examination.

    The second one which needs an examination is wages. One issue of wages is portable medical benefits. Members have talked about it. The unions and the employers have been talking about it for some time, and the issue is simply stated. A young worker starting out can work for any employer and the employer will take him. He is still healthy. If he falls ill, the employer bears the medical burden. An older worker, already with medical conditions, wanting to change jobs has a very serious problem, because no new employer wants to take him and carry that burden of taking on his medical benefits.

    So how do we provide workers with portable medical benefits so that when he changes jobs from one employer to another, he carries his perks with him, in the same way as he carries the CPF benefits with him? Right now, for employer-provided benefits, if the employer retrenches or goes bust, he loses it. But we need to move from that to something which is portable, which means a change from the existing employer-provided, employer-paid benefits, which means something for workers to get used to.

    Secondly, on wages, we have to think about retrenchment benefits. It is the traditional way for workers to tide them over a period of unemployment. It is based on length of service. The longer you work, the more your retrenchment benefits, and it is unfunded, which means that when the time comes, the company looks for money to pay for these retrenchment benefits. This causes a problem. From the point of view of the person who is retrenched, it is good, because he gets something. But the

Column: 405



    unions have found that sometimes the benefits of a long-serving employee are a huge drain on the company's financial resources. And the companies may be unable to pay or it could be that they can pay but it will endanger the jobs of the remaining workers, because if you pay the retrenchment benefits, you are no longer viable and able to continue operating.

    So the system has weaknesses. And as our business cycles become shorter as more workers find themselves in between jobs, we have got to find a better way to do this. One idea which the unions have thought about and have floated with the employers is to get the employers and employees to put aside a certain amount of money every year while the company is still in good health, for example, in an enhanced bonus system which will vest in their employees over a period of time. So you cannot draw it out straightaway. It builds up, it is yours. After a certain period of time, you can draw it. And you replace the traditional retrenchment benefits with such a scheme. It is an individual-based fund. Then when the employee is retrenched, you do not depend on the state of the company then, but you can draw down what you have earned earlier in this fund, in this enhanced bonus system, until you can find a new job. Some employers already do this. It is something which needs to be studied. It may not work for all of the companies. We should look at this as well as other ideas. But we have to examine the problem of retrenchment benefits.

    The key idea, when we talk about wages, is to free up the labour market, to create more jobs. The more restrictions we may have, the more rules we have, the more difficult it is we make for people to join jobs and leave jobs, the more reluctant employers will be to take on workers and the higher our unemployment rate will be.

    Mr Ahmad Khalis earlier this afternoon suggested, for example, setting up a mechanism for employers to have to justify to the Ministry before they can retrench their workers and must give reasons and also answer for how much

Column: 406

they are paying their senior executives. It is a well-intentioned proposal, but it is a counter-productive proposal. Because the result of this is for companies when they would otherwise hire workers to ask themselves, "Do I really want to take on somebody whom I may not need for the long term, whom I may have difficulty letting go off when the business conditions change, whom I may be stuck with?" And the answer is, "Better not, work overtime with the existing workers, don't hire extra hands."

    This is not a theoretical risk. It is a real problem. In Germany, which has the tightest laws for firing workers and is the most difficult of all to let go of workers, they have the highest unemployment rates, and it is not a coincidence. It is because employers make the calculations: too hard to drop, better do not hire. So the key idea which we must follow is to free up the labour market, make it easy for people to change jobs and then we will be able to have high employment rates, not unemployment rates.

    The third issue which we have to consider is taxation. Lower direct taxes, lower corporate and personal income taxes are essential if we are going to prosper in the next phase. They are essential because of competitiveness reasons. Other countries have been bringing down their direct tax rates drastically over the years and continuing to do so, and we have to be competitive with them. The Europeans, some of them, the Germans are 30%-plus corporate tax. If we are equal to them, there is no reason why they will consider coming to Singapore. Others are bringing direct taxes down, we have to do the same.

    We have to attract talent intensive service industries to Singapore. We are not talking just about factories where hundreds of millions of dollars of investments, one or two employees ordered to go, he goes to Singapore. We are talking about fund managers, we are talking about IT companies, creative companies, people, movies, software. The people are the company. The people are high-earning people. If your tax is not competitive, the person says, "I'm not going to

Column: 407

Singapore." The company will not be here. We have seen it. Our promoting agencies - MAS, IDA, EDB - repeatedly, when they want to try and bring activities to Singapore, they are asked, "How much more tax do I have to pay?" So that is a serious reason to bring down not just the corporate tax but the personal tax as well.

    We have to bring down direct taxes to encourage entrepreneurship because an entrepreneur goes in, if you want him to risk everything, then he must have the chance of gaining a great deal. And if you say, if you risk everything, you lose, too bad, I give you a pat on the back, perhaps a medal. But you gain, you win, I will tax you 30%-40%, you would not get entrepreneurship. It is one basic reason why there are not so many entrepreneurs in Europe as in America because, in America, tax rates are lower, and Europe is not worth your while. In short, we have to bring our direct tax rates down to encourage more investments to grow the economy and, ultimately, which is most important for us, to create good well-paying jobs for Singaporeans. Unless you bring the direct tax rates down, you cannot do that.

    At the same time, we cannot just bring the direct tax rates down. You have got to balance the budget. If we simply cut direct taxes, we will end up with a structural deficit, meaning whether the economy is up or down, the Government cannot balance its books and we will run a budget deficit. For example, Hong Kong now has quite a serious fiscal problem because they have lost one major source of revenue, which is land sales. Their tax rates are very low, their budget is in deficit. The Financial Secretary hopes to bring it back into balance over a period of seven years, but there are no easy solutions and raising taxes is very, very difficult. But we have to balance the budget and a balanced budget, in fact a modest surplus maintained over many years, has been one of the fundamental reasons why the Singapore dollar has been strong, why inflation has been low, why everybody's CPF balances and

Column: 408

savings have had their value protected. So unless we protect the balanced budget, we are going to have a very fundamental problem.

    So if we are going to bring direct taxes down and we are going to balance the budget, there is only one conclusion, that we have to bring up indirect taxes. What are indirect taxes? We have car taxes. We could raise those if they are not high enough. But I am not sure many Members will agree that they are not high enough. And there is GST, a broad-based tax which applies to everything, paid by everybody, weighs lightly on the whole economy because it is very well spread, efficient to collect and a stable source of revenue for the exchequer, whether the economy goes up or the economy goes down.

One, timing, to be only done when the economy is on a firmer footing. Therefore, if we are going to adjust the GST, we have to buffer the overall burden on these lower income groups. And we also have to address specific concerns over certain vital essentials - education, healthcare, public transport.

household. And in addition to that, we also had reassurance on education, on healthcare, on public transport, on specific critical items so that nobody will be alarmed, panicked into thinking that this is going to be an unbearable burden on him, which it is not. We reduced direct taxes in 1994 and, in subsequent years, whenever our finances strengthened, we gradually brought direct taxes down again. So, today, our corporate tax is 24 1/2%, our personal tax is 26 1/2%. Because of that, our economy grew after 1994-1995, 1996; 1997, we did well; 1998, the Asian crisis came, we still had positive growth; 1999, we picked up; 2000, we had a boom year; 2001, the US economy tanked, the electronics sector went into a slump, we went down. It has been important to us that we did this because we are not just a free market economy, we are also a nation and we are also investing in our people and building a population together. These social safety nets will remain major elements of our social compact. It is part of the deal. You are a Singaporean, this is the package. You work, you do well, but to start off with, here are things which you will get, not quite a birth right, but which every Singaporean will get. Our experience with the Economic Downturn Relief Scheme, which we introduced last year, is quite salutary. MPs will have first-hand experience. We did it because we needed to do it, because we were in a sharp recession. So we said up

to $200 for three months. But quite a number of Singaporeans spread the word around that the Government is distributing money. And they came to queue up for the hand-out because it would have been remiss of them not to come and take this opportunity. And they came and we met them at the meet-the-people session.     Mr Speaker, Sir, may I now speak about the role of the Government. Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked what is the Government for. The people have elected us. What do you expect of the Government?
