I realise that for every action, and that includes non-action, there is a reaction, there is a consequence. Therefore, how we react to the changes around us today will determine our social, economic and political destiny.

    Hence, my question, Sir, is how are we responding to the changes today? Do we respond as a victim of change, thereby feeling helpless, willy-nilly? Or do we respond as a critic of change, thereby generating negative energy? Do we respond as a bystander, awaiting for all to move before hopping onto the bandwagon? Or do we respond to change as a navigator, seeking to lead and reap, and write our own story? Every generation has a story. What is the story for our current and future generation?

    On a national level, I am thankful that we have a `navigator' Government that chooses to grab the bull by its horns and ride on the waves of change. Our Government realises that we need to constantly check on ourselves and stay relevant to the dynamos of the world. We are at this milestone check now, and we have promised to `leave no stone unturned'.

Personal response and choices

    On an individual level, however, the picture is less clear. My question here is: Are we aware, as individuals, that we do have a choice? Earlier on, the hon. Member, Dr Vivian Balakrishnan, stated that his junior asked him why he should be fighting for Singapore and dying for Singapore. And the hon. Member, Dr Wang Kai Yuen, asked him whether it was a result of our education or social system or family upbringing. I suppose my question is: Is it because we have been

Column: 431

so caught up with our own work, at our individual, adult or parent level, that we have not spent enough time to inculcate some of these values, such as emotional rootedness, that Dr Vivian spoke about, in our children? It appears that more than 40 years of prosperity have bred a new cohort of Singaporeans who have not made a habit of making up their own minds and whipping up enough courage to pursue their passions. There is no denial that many of us would prefer to hit the well-beaten path.

    Could it be that some of us still live in the shadows of the 1960s' state of emergency? Or could it be that we have been running so relentlessly up the economic ladder, sparing little time to pause, reflect and dwell deeper into what we really want or what we are really about? Or is it that we have a Government that cares, and cares so much, that we often look to our Government for all directions and answers to our life - from economic means to business ideas to personal life choices? Obviously, I have not heeded that call yet.

    Sir, it was once said that when the US sneezes, Singapore catches pneumonia. Similarly, when our Government opens a door, many people rush in there without questioning why. Obviously, when something goes wrong, the Government gets the blame. Sometimes, the Government also gets away with it, because there simply does not seem to be another way out. Many of us are in our comfort zones, and some perhaps do not see or even want a way out. I cannot agree more with the hon. Member Koo Tsai Kee who said that as we become richer, we become more kiasu, or scared to lose. I myself was in that trap before. Years ago, I sold my car and was in the midst of shopping for a bigger and better car. When a friend asked me out, I told her that I could not because I had no car. She screamed and said: "You have no car but you have `kahs', meaning my legs. So what is your problem?" Sir, I was awakened. I realised that years ago when all I had was a backpack on my back, I was mobile and dexterous. I could go anywhere I wanted, to pursue my dreams.

Column: 432

Not kiasu, not kiasi. As I accumulate some wealth, I became hesitant and cautious, thereby suffering from paralysis via analysis. What an irony!

    Sir, but I realise I am not alone in my predicament. I have come across many people at the meet-the-people session who are handicapped by their material trappings, and they could not harness new horizons as a result. We know of many retrenched workers who place more importance on job types and job distances, even in the face of mounting debts. Many will rather wait for the right job and apply for financial assistance meanwhile. Sir, the Government can only do so much.

People and Government

    In Jack Neo's recent production `I Not Stupid', which has been mentioned many times in this Parliament, there was this mother who had so over-provided for the well-being of her child, that the child did not even know how to butter his own bread. What will happen when mummy is no longer around or as able?

    We need to put our citizens in the driver seat. Not one person, not a small group of people, but all Singaporeans at large. We must get our people to say `what I can do?', rather than `what can the Government do?' In our quest to remake Singapore, let us focus on encouraging and facilitating our people to think and work for what they believe in, rather than provide all the answers. Let each one take ownership of his destiny, and switch gear from a reactive to a proactive mode. We must switch gear, from a government-centric approach to a people-centric approach.

    I am not advocating the abdication of the Government's role or responsibility. That just cannot be the case. I am advocating shared responsibility for a common destiny. The Government should be after all, by the people, from the people and for the people. For what is a government without popular support? In Karl Marx's theory about the bourgeois and proletariat, polarisation will lead to a revolution. We are far from that but we must be mindful of any divide or gap.

Column: 433



Needed space

    Bridging will certainly mean more risks and take more space. However, this is the necessary space needed to germinate a self-conscious society, the space needed to encourage an enterprising population, the space to experiment, fall and rejuvenate. Rome was not built in a day, we must be patient and tolerant. However, we do need to accelerate our learning curve in Internet time, in real time, and for the sceptical ones, for real this time.

Core value system as anchor

    So where do we start? I suggest we start with the basics, with the fundamentals. There was a time where quick fixes and get-rich-quick dot-com companies ruled the market. That did not last very long. When the Internet bubble burst and the dot-coms became dot `cons' and dot `gones', value stocks and fundamentally strong companies prevailed. Similarly, let us invest in our own value system. It is only when we know what we are about, then can we battle external pressures. Sun Tze once said: Zhi bi zhi ji, bai zhan bai sheng ( , ). Translated literally, it means "Know thy enemy, know thyself, hundred battles fought, hundred battles won." To a certain extent, we are only what we think, so let us jointly identify and strengthen our shared core values, let it permeate the different strata of our society, not just via talk, but via conscious efforts to externalise these values in our daily activities. In other words, let us walk our talk.

Adjust responses to harness opportunities

    Once we know what we stand for, then let us adjust our reactions to change. We are in a challenging time and we have crisis to surmount. The Chinese term for crisis is weiji (    ). Weiji means weixian de shi hou, bi you jihui ( , ). It implies that there are always opportunities amidst adversity. After all, good value cheap sales surface only in hard times. Hence, if we can change our collective dominant thought from that of facing adversity to

Column: 434

finding opportunities, then the net result must be better.

    We have to break through glass ceilings and expand our mental box. As water has no fixed form, survival has no fixed rules. In the industrial age, a hardworking, experienced and highly-educated person is almost made for life. In the information age, experience and age can become liabilities, not assets, if we choose not to respond positive to changes. Many people will become contract workers or freelance consultants in this era. This change will not only affect jobs and careers; it affects the entire lifestyle. We need to take stock of where we are now, and where we want to go, in order to harness the regional and global opportunities.

Stock take: Government ok, people?

    When it comes to taking stock, I think the Government has been prudent in its spending and some say, aggressive in its investments and earnings, and therefore we have built up enough resources to tackle the challenges and to harness opportunities. However, the same cannot be said at the individual level. Many residents came to me with numerous bills unpaid and little resources to last. Many of these bills relate to lifestyle expenses. I am very, very concerned. Here, again, I refer to the value system of our people. Does more mean better? "Money no enough!" - that is the common outcry of many Singaporeans. The truth is, money is never going to be enough as long as we are buying the latest hi-fi, upgrading, having posh furniture, and keep paying them in instalments. Are we heading towards becoming a society of consumerism and debt? The latest report in 2001 showed a 28% increase in credit card debts and 19% increase in personal, not business, bankruptcy. This could be conveniently attributed to the recession, but the underlying cause is largely spending on credit. With anticipated slowdown in wage increment, we must not develop a new generation of big spenders with huge debts and be trapped in the obsessive pursuit of the 5 `Cs'. Do we want to hold our future generation hostage to debts

Column: 435

created today? The answer must be `no'. Spending of what one earns is not wrong, but spending beyond one's means runs contrary to the basic economic formula of save, invest and accumulate.

    I realise that for some people, poverty is a stark reality. For others, it could just be a state of mind. I would like to ask, is it the high cost of living, or the cost of high living, that leaves us breathless? I believe the answer lies somewhere between the two ends. Perhaps instead of working non-stop to acquire more and more, we could re-evaluate our financial objectives, lest we end up chasing our own tail. While we work hard to make money, we could also learn to make money work harder for us. A particular credit card company urges us not to `leave home without it'. I say, if you cannot resist temptations, you better leave home without it.

    Good financial discipline and the attitude towards money can be nurtured from young. Young children should learn about the importance of savings. Older students can be encouraged to operate school cooperatives, thereby incubate entrepreneurs who will learn about the value of money and financial management. With social and domestic sciences in our academic curriculum, perhaps it is time for us to consider including financial science as well. We can increase FQ, or financial quotient, this way.

    Adults, parents and retirees too can benefit from such knowledge and proper understanding of money attitude and tools. Yesterday, the hon. Member Mr Lim Boon Heng wondered aloud if there is a way to reconcile the lack of retirement funds with perhaps too much housing. May I offer my observation. Our CPF savings for the ordinary folks is a powerful retirement tool, but only if it is properly understood and utilised. To illustrate using the Census 2001 report of an average household income of $4,943 per month, and assuming an average household works for 30 years of their life, they would potentially be able to accumulate a combined CPF savings of $1.037 million,

Column: 436

based on an average compound interest rate of 3% per annum. In other words, the average Singaporean household is potentially a millionaire household. If only people realise this and moderate their demand for a nice roof with their need for a nice retirement nest-egg, retirement funding would become more achievable. The problem here is, Sir, that many Singaporeans do not perceive their CPF savings as their retirement nest-egg. What they perceive their CPF savings is money stuck in the Government's coffer. As such, they will seek all ways to withdraw it. Housing withdrawals have no cap, and is perceived as a status symbol, and a means to release their funds from CPF. I agree with Mr Lim that taking a huge mortgage loan in one's 50s when one cannot afford it is disastrous.

    Sir, we have designed a world-class retirement system, the CPF system. It is now time for us to go one step further to ensure that our people fully understand its prowess and utilise it accordingly. While the CPF liberalisation is much welcomed, systematic education is needed to prevent unsystematic leakages. May I suggest that the CPF Board and HDB look into the possibility of playing a much bigger role in advising Singaporeans in their finances? It may sound out of this world, but I know and I understand that these are not traditional roles, but perhaps we can think out of the box and either build or outsource some of these services to start a financial counselling process for very major purchases - much like that of marriage counselling. The emphasis should be on the attitudes and habits around money, rather than on technical calculations, as is being done today. Certainly, a financially savvy population will save us from the need for more financial hand-outs and more taxes.

    Sir, I am under no illusion that financial literacy would eliminate all financial hardships. I believe the Government has a social obligation to help the less able and less fortunate. I join the calls of my colleagues in this House to seek ways to lower the cost of basic necessities, like public transport, healthcare and utilities. In the Sengkang part of Punggol North

Column: 437

division, where void deck coffeeshops are replaced by airconditioned food courts and neighbourhood centres come in the form of an airconditioned mall, my residents not only miss the hawker centres there with a heavy heart, but also with a very affected pocket. The cost of living has indeed shot up. This problem is compounded where there are job loss and wage cuts.

    There is another group that has caught my attention lately. This is the `asset so-so, but cash poor' group of people that is sandwiched between the haves and the have-nots. These are citizens who are faced with financial difficulties, despite owning a roof. They have paid so much for their property that little is left to see them through their silver days. In 20 to 30 years' time, some of these properties would have only 60 years or less of lease. The current legislation makes it difficult to borrow on such property, especially if it is HDB property. Can they downgrade? It is easier said than done.

    Could we then look into the needs of this group of people by revisiting the legislation, and perhaps under very stringent conditions, based on compassionate grounds, consider acting as a lender of last resort? I know DPM has just said that the Government cannot be a last resort of any kind. While I concede that that is true and we have to be very careful, if it is undesirable, then can we explore other options? For example, relook at the mortgage policy for this group of people so that they may use their last available assets to ease their retirement years. The problem is there and more will be affected as time passes. We need to tackle these issues.

    Sir, we have a Government that has continuously shown its wits and tenacity - ensuring Singapore remains a premier business hub. We do not ask "Who moved my cheese?", but proactively look for new cheese and create new cheese. We have a Government with great financial wisdom, one that adopts a policy of building up and protecting our reserves so that we can seize the opportunities to become bigger and stronger. Our Government has made

Column: 438

a conscious choice to do so. What about our people? We now need to foster this culture in our people so that they too can one day lead the dance with our Government, at the world stage, to the same tune. Let us provide the space so that our youths, our people, can grow. To quote an old adage, `Give a child a fish, you feed him for a day. Teach a child to fish, you feed him for life.' It is therefore my hope that we - the people, the public and the private sectors - can establish mutual trust and cooperation, not just to ease the possible pains of change, but to also embrace the winds of change. Not just as `you', not just as `I', but as `we'. United we stand, divided we fall.

found in these events. The general tone of the President's Address is that we must be ready to face hard times and be vigilant in the face of tougher competition and to protect our people from the unexpected.

Only 1,600 new jobs were created in the year 2001, compared to 108,500 in the year 2000.

They will formulate and implement risk management and strategy plans that focus on economic fundamentals, competitiveness, cash flow, profitability and the factors that drive these forward. But it is not as easy as it sounds. As it requires robust planning and execution of integrated plans, we borrowed lessons

Column: 440

learned from past events. There are no short cuts, no magic wands. It must surely require the support and will of the power and the resourcefulness of our Government to work together in close consultation to improve our economy so that businesses can thrive.

The Government must continue to adopt a humane management of its citizens and put its primary concern on the well-being of those people.     Mr Speaker, Sir, at this point, please allow me to use some lessons from the business world to demonstrate the resourcefulness of people in adapting to changes and without losing their dignity and pride in the process. Firstly, in transforming Singapore from the present economy to one that will be economically stronger, we must be careful in not destroying its identity, such as its cultural diversity. We can look at the case of a business entity, such as Nissan, which was a struggling Japanese motor giant, and learn from its blueprint for survival. Nissan became a huge conglomerate when the economic climate was conducive to Japan. But as high costs and the inability to recognise its force, faults seeped in. It struggled to turn a profit for eight years in the 1990s. Its operation generated notoriously low margins and it was estimated that Nissan gave away US$1,000 for every car it sold in the United States due to competition from better-known brands. At the same time, Japanese factories alone could produce

Column: 441

almost a million more cars a year than the company sold.

    If nothing was done to turn the company around, Nissan would cease to exist. Nissan had to make changes and, while doing so, they have to protect the company's identity and the self-esteem of its people. These two goals, making changes and safeguarding identity, can easily come into conflict. Pursuing them both entails a difficult and sometimes precarious balancing act. Nissan managed them by mobilising its own executives in teams and, through a set of cross-functional teams, identified and spearheaded the radical changes that had to be made. These changes that were implemented went against the grain of not only Nissan's long-standing operating practices but also of some of the behavioral norms of Japanese society.

Less than three years later, Nissan, at the turn of the century, is profitable again. The robust turnaround at Nissan shows that we have to respect the dignity of the people, even as you challenge them to overturn deep-seated traditions.

    The Economic Review Committee, set up early this year to review our country's performance, is somewhat like the cross-functional teams set up in Nissan, and will be Singapore's attempt in the right direction in reviving its economy. And we were told that no stones would be left unturned in the process. But when deciding on the course of action to take, the Government must remain sensitive to the varied cultures of Singaporeans and their dignity.

    Secondly, before Singapore could recover from the slowing-down effects of the Asian crisis that drastically reduced the economic activities of regional countries, the United States of America, Singapore's main business partner in

Column: 442

terms of trade, suffered an overnight economic breakdown after the September 11th terrorist attack.

    In addition, we have discovered that disaster has now been redefined after 11th September 2001, and Singapore has to take another look at its economic and social continuity plans. The accounting firm, Deloitte & Touche, already knew the value of a plan when it was forced to evacuate its office at the World Trade Centre in 1993 after a car bomb blew up the bottom of the building. The plan did not specifically direct 3,500 employees to drop their briefcases and dash through a shower of debris, smoke and dust as two huge buildings thundered down behind them. But, as the managing partners regrouped at a safe distance, they knew the plan called for them to head across the Hudson River to a branch office in New Jersey. There, they took out a big, nice red book, the firm's business continuity plan. With that, they proceeded through an excruciating 3-stage process of contacting all employees, reconnecting them to the firm and its clientele, and recovering the firm's position in the marketplace.

Some 2,700 worked between the 43rd and 74th floor of the South Tower. All but six survived the attack. The company survived too. Under its business continuity plan, it has already determined its fundamental activities and how to support them. On the Monday after the attack, when the stock markets opened, Morgan Stanley was offering business as usual.

NESTS, short for the National Emergency System, formed under the auspices of the Ministry of Home Affairs, and that the Government is working closely with the private sector to ensure that the nation's infrastructure will still function, should a disaster strike.

Column: 444

today's hospital and medical facilities, that hospital was outclassed. to nourish the very humanity that can make people and a country great.

    Let me return to the Singapore Home. The constituents of the Singapore Home are the different ethnic communities. Family systems theory noted that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts. The strength of the Singapore Home is not merely the existence of the different ethnic communities, but rather the dynamic interaction between them. These interactions are key ingredients to the development of social support networks and systems in the Singapore Home.

    Sir, social support systems are critical in the home as they often buffer the impact of domestic violence. While the global economic market may be a potentially abusive partner, the abuse may not come from the economic sphere alone. The threat of global terrorism calls for Singaporeans to look within ourselves and assess the support system that we have. The analogy of domestic violence that I have used is not unintentional. Indeed, the threat of terrorism is no more a foreign and external issue. It has become a domestic issue on the threats of violence.

    Sir, prior to September 11 and the JI arrests, we seem to take our social support network for granted. Not only are social support systems critical during times of crisis, they are indeed our first line of defence. Our social support network is not a static phenomenon. It is dynamic and fluid. It requires constant effort at building and sustaining.

    Sir, in 1994, I conducted a study on social support network of low income families. One aspect of the study was to assess the role of social support network as buffers to economic hardship. What surprises me is that families are less likely

Column: 449

to have individuals from different ethnic groups as part of their social network, even when they are neighbours. This spurred me to include cross-cultural understanding in my classes at NUS. In the class, one of the exercises that I usually task my students to do is to interview five persons who are different from them ethnically, to understand their values and belief systems. Many of the students have difficulty doing so, even when the exercise did not limit them to talking to strangers only, ie, they can actually interview friends that they had known even before they entered university. Many have difficulty completing that exercise. Each time I give them a quiz on what they know about each other's community, they fail miserably. When September 11 took place, one senior Chinese grassroots leader came up to me and asked why do Muslim women need to wear the tudung. I am sure many of us have many questions about each other's values and practices.

    What do these findings and anecdotes indicate? I am not too sure. Our integration policies are in place. Yet, we are still seeing such outcomes. Perhaps the outcome could have been worse if the policies had not been in place. Sir, it is not surprising that people gravitate to their own kind and remain in their comfort zones. I am not advocating for more Government intervention, but for Singaporeans to realise that they need to be committed to the process of inter-ethnic integration.

    When the threat of terrorism came knocking on our doors recently, the issue of inter-ethnic relation was pushed to the forefront. It is a timely reminder that we cannot be complacent. We need to recognise that building and sustaining relationships and networks require effort and commitment. It is not enough for us to merely smile at our neighbours or get our children to dress in each other's ethnic costumes during Racial Harmony Day. These are good starting points but we cannot remain at the starting block. Each community must make the effort to reach out to the other communities. The best way is, of course, to open the common

Column: 450

spaces. Yes, we do recognise and respect the private spaces. But to build relationships, we need to step out of our private spaces and enter the public spaces more readily.

    The process of cross-cultural understanding and interaction requires a high level of self-awareness and openness. While we are presently "gung-ho" about wanting to improve interaction and getting to know each other better, we must be mindful of the potential threat of ethnocentrism. Each community must respect the values and cultures of others and avoid the perception that one's values are better than the others'. This is ethnocentrism. The issue of religion and value systems is so intrinsically rooted in each individual and community that it is often all too sensitive to discuss it in the open. Self-awareness is crucial. Mutual respect is imminent. The work of the IRCC must take into account these key factors for it to succeed.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, as we continue to nurture the Singapore Home with strong inter-ethnic bonds, another significant pillar of the home that needs attention is the family. There has been talk that many Singaporean families are highly stressed. Indicators that our families are stressed include incidences of juvenile delinquency, marital dissolution, domestic violence, drug abuse, etc, in these families. While statistics show that these problems are either on a decline or are stabilised, we cannot pretend that they are not important. Often times, these problems do not happen in isolation - they actually co-exist and we typically have what social workers call multi-problem families.

    The systemic effects of any of these problems are tremendous. A family who has a juvenile delinquent not only deals with the behavioral problems presented by the teenager, but also the effects on the other family members. Marital relationships are often strained with couples placing blame on one another. The compensatory efforts at dealing with the delinquent child often result in unintentional neglect of the other children. The

Column: 451

potential effects go on. The juvenile delinquent, if not well rehabilitated, may graduate to be adult offenders.

    Sir, families need to be strengthened to prevent the onset of such incidences. The family today is different from the family of yesterday. Yes, in its form and function, one may argue that there is no difference. However, the dynamics of role performances must change to keep up with the changing environments. I read with great interest the issues raised in the last Parliament as it debated on family-friendly practices. I should not belabour the point nor repeat the points raised. However, I would like to reiterate the need for us to recognise some of the changes that families are subjected to, and respond with a clear message that we support these changes through relevant policies and legislation.

    Sir, to strengthen our families, we need to ensure that emotional bonds between each family member are strong, such that support would be available when called upon. The emotional bond between mother and child is a given and, often times, assumed to be a natural order of things. However, the emotional bonds between fathers and children are considered rather alien, especially in the context of Asian cultures. Fathers are seen more as disciplinarians in families. They are not supposed to be emotional. Our boys are still raised not to show their emotions. Sociological and psychological research has begun to show the importance of father-child bonds in the development of children and families. Bonds do not appear overnight. They need to be cultivated and nurtured. In my work with fathers, I have heard many lament that they do not know how to relate to their adolescent children, as much as they realise the importance of doing so.

    Sir, bonds of fathering must be developed when children are young and most dependent. I am pleased to note that the Government has made provisions for

Column: 452

paternity leave for fathers to be involved in the lives of their new born. The current three days of paternity leave is a good start, though I would encourage the Government to consider extending it. And I think we have the next five years to discuss that. An infant child is at his most dependent state, and this is the most excellent time for a father to establish the bond with the child.

    Another opportunity for bonding is when the child is ill. Today, we have child sick leave only for female civil servants. Sir, this seems to send the message that when a child is sick, it is the responsibility of the mother to care for the child. I would recommend that the child sick leave benefit be extended to male civil servants to send a consistent and clear message that fathers are equally responsible and capable of looking after a sick child.

    There are other opportunities like facilitating father's presence in parent-teacher meetings in schools. I have often given parenting talks in schools, and one clear observation which is supported by many school principals, is that, often times, only mothers attend these talks and meetings. Where are the fathers? Working? Many mothers who attend these meetings are working mothers too. Children often read the absence of fathers as their disinterest in their education and the lives of their children. These are opportunities lost for fathers. The result is a distancing of the children from their fathers.

    As a society, we need to send a clear message that fathers must be involved in the total development of their children, as do mothers. In this regard, may I be so trivial to suggest that the Ministry of the Environment ensure that every public men's room be equipped with diaper changing facilities. Once, I had a hard time finding a place to change my son's diaper after I took him for swimming, as I could not find a place in the men's room to do so. But, rest assured, I did not go to the ladies' room. There are ways of doing it though. We need to normalise such behaviours and encourage fathers to feel

Column: 453

comfortable about doing such fathering practices in public.

    Sir, gone are the days where fathers can be contented with merely bringing home the bacon, or the halal meat, or the vegetables. He is expected to share in the parenting and household responsibilities, just as his wife is sharing in his traditional role of income provider. The family bonds can be strengthened with mutually supporting partners who share the same vision and responsibilities. Sir, the measures above may seem small and insignificant in themselves but, put together, I am confident, as shown by many researchers, that they would go a long way in ensuring that children are raised as successful and confident adults in a safe, secure and supportive environment, with the presence of both fathers and mothers. Sir, as the saying goes, a journey of a thousand miles begins with one single footstep.

    Sir, the sharing of parenting roles and responsibilities in families is even more critical as we study the impact of restructuring the economy on Singaporean families. As women are a force to be reckoned with in the economic sphere, they too need to constantly upgrade themselves to remain employable and relevant. Such demands have direct implications on how families negotiate their times in relation to parenting responsibilities and individual needs for training and upgrading. It is thus most critical now that we begin to sow the seeds of positive fathering practices as we prepare Singaporeans moving into the new economic structures. As we remake Singapore, we need to also remake our perception of the family - a key pillar of the Singapore Home.

    As I talk about the new age father, the way the Singapore Government has been described comes to mind. Paternalistic, patronizing, patriarchal are adjectives that have been used to describe the Government. Yes, the children of Singapore have been raised well with a father figure who knows what is best for them. I have a similar father too - dogmatic, disciplinarian and no buts.

Column: 454



    But the children of tomorrow are different. The fathering practices that my father used on me no longer work with my children. I have to be present in their lives. I have to listen to them - listen not just with my ears, but with my eyes and, more importantly, with my heart. Recognising this, I try to reach out to my father. The initial hesitancy is slowly changing. He is more able to express his emotions. He can change.

    There have been calls to remake the Government. I think the Government should continue being the father of Singaporeans. But the new age father also nurtures his child and provides the emotional support when needed. He is more than a disciplinarian, more than the decision maker. He is a friend who has built strong bonds when the child is an infant. It is timely for the Government to invest in these bonds today. The children are reaching out to the father. Like my father, I am confident that the Government is capable of responding to this call. Take time to listen, take time to nurture, take time to provide the emotional support. I am confident it will go a long way in building up a Singapore Home that is united, strong, resilient and supportive.

    Sir, I am as old as independent Singapore is. I have seen how my parents built a strong home for my eight siblings and I - from the kampong house at Coronation Road to the 1-room rental flat in Toa Payoh and, subsequently, to a 3-room purchase flat in Toa Payoh where they still live today. Like many other first generation Singaporeans, they overcame insurmountable challenges. It is a process that is on-going. Today, like many other young couples, my wife and I strive to build a strong home for our children. I have spoken of nurturing the Singapore Home - preparing ourselves for the expectation of Singapore's marriage partner, ie, the global economic market, strengthening the bonds between communities, strengthening families through enhancing the role of fathers, and developing new age fathering practices in

Column: 455

the relationship between the Government and the people.

    Sir, this is my vision as a Singaporean, as a young father of another generation of Singaporeans. For Singapore to survive, we need to accept and move towards a common destiny. Singaporeans must share the same vision. My vision for the remade Singapore is one in which the people are economically successful, yet rooted and bonded to the family, individually confident, yet socially networked, global in outlook, yet Singaporean in identity. These are ingredients that will continue to nurture the Singapore H ome.

    Sir, I support the motion.
